Legal_Issue: Infringement of the '576 Patent by Sandoz's generic fenofibrate composition
Validity of the patent under Canadian law
Evidence_Assessment: Expert testimony on particle size, co-micronization, dissolution profiles
Support for sound prediction in patent claims
Burden_of_Proof: Fournier failed to prove infringement on the balance of probabilities
Credibility_Factor: Expert testimonies were considered and evaluated
Legal_Rule: A patent is presumed valid unless proven otherwise
Infringement requires meeting all claim limitations
Invalidity can be based on anticipation, obviousness, overbreadth, lack of utility, insufficient disclosure, or ambiguity
Grounds_for_Claim: Challenges to validity: anticipation, obviousness, overbreadth, lack of utility
Judicial_Review_Outcome: Sandoz allowed to proceed without prohibition order
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Proceedings included cross-examinations and expert analysis
Applicant_Challenge: Sandoz sought approval to market generic fenofibrate
Court_Result: Fournier did not meet burden of proof; application dismissed
Defendant_Response: Sandoz argued non-infringement and patent invalidity
Remedy_Sought: Prevent Sandoz from marketing generic version pending patent expiry
Legal_Provision: Patent Act provisions on validity and infringement
Outcome_of_Review: Sandoz permitted to proceed with generic drug marketing
